I'm not big on talking on the phone, but when you're trying to make appointments for outings such as fishing, boating, rock-climbing or any other local adventures, you need to have some sort of phone coverage. The first night we were there, I noticed no hot water. So the next morning, we made sure we were the first to shower so that we weren't forced to take cold showers. Overall, I found that there were indeed other hotels that we could have stayed but were not listed on travel sites, so I am taking every initiative to make sure these other locations are listed so no one feels that Casa Grande is their only option. We certainly felt this way when it came to the restaurant. We found numerous restaurants that offered much better service and a broader menu. One of our favorites was lakeside in Utuado called Rancho Marina which is run by Vivian and Harry. They offered great service and a very nice setting as well as a great menu.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful, Remote, Quaint, Loud”
Reviews.Author: metamer6
Reviews.Content: Disclaimer: My wife and I were put in a room right above the road, which means every 2-3 hours, when a car raced by, it was very noise. I imagine other rooms would yield a better experience than ours. If you stay here, try very much to get a room away from the road! I think 3 1/2 stars is more accurate, but I'll have to settle for three. My wife and I are not too picky. We pretty much keep to ourselves and don't require much attention in terms of service and we certainly don't demand 'fancy' accommodations. I really like the location of Casa Grande, it really is in the middle of nowhere, surrounded by lush rain forest. The roads are extremely windy in the area, but I thought it was fun (in our rental car :) If you like to sit around and look at the rainforest and read a book, do yoga or maybe go on some hikes, then this place will be great for you. My wife and I stayed here two nights and went to Arecibo Observatory (which was cool) and Rio Camuy (which was also cool). Other than that there is nothing to do around here. The closest town, Utuado, is also small with nothing to do. You can pretty much plan on eating at the restaurant in the hotel, unless you want to adventure to Utuado and dig something up (probably 20 or so minutes away by car). The service was slow and carefree (as they say in Fiji: "no hurries, no worries"). We thought the food was decent though, and slightly overpriced. The room was basically like a Motel 6 (hey you're in the middle of the rainforest), but the windows aren't covered in glass, only a screen for insects and shutters that close to block light. That means if you are in the room next to the road, any cars driving by are VERY loud, and I'm a moderately heavy sleeper. Also the walls are super thin, so be prepared to hear everything that your neighbors are doing, as well as their screaming children. Maybe bring some Ambien. In Sum: I liked the location (I think rainforests are cool) I would like the room if it was away from the road The service was poor, but that's just a Puerto Rico thing, so deal with it I would probably recommend it to a friend just for the one of a kind experience. Just get a room away from the road! Also be prepared with what you want to do all day in advance, you will need to entertain yourself here. Oh, did I mention get a room away from the road?

Reviews.Title: “Amazing location, beautiful and peaceful”
Reviews.Author: 2_5travellers
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Casa Grande for 3 nights in March. We really enjoyed our stay there and would come back, without a doubt. The sounds at night are wonderful; something we'd expect to hear only on a National Geographic special. The room was clean and pleasant, and the hammock on the little balcony was a very nice touch. Staff were friendly and helpful, and arrived to tidy up our room every day. The breakfast was very good. The dinner menu was a little limited, but also good and, again, we very much enjoyed the setting in the evening. Another nice touch was Toupinou (sp?), the proprietor's very friendly dog who greeted us and other guests, was great with our 1 1/2 year old son, and even saw us off. We concur with other reviewers that the cabin walls are thin. There are four units per cabin, and I'm sure our neighbors heard our son complaining one morning. We certainly heard one of our neighbors "doin' it"; however, they also caused the entire cabin to shake, which was a little unsettling at first. Ultimately, neither the noise nor the motion were a big deal. The road to the Casa Grande was winding and narrow, but more fun than frightening even when we were arriving after dark. Just drive slowly, as appropriate, and do not be afraid to announce your presence at blind corners by beeping your horn (the local residents certainly do). We only have a couple comments regarding ways our stay could have been improved just a little. First, because the first evening we were there it was a little chilly (for Puerto Rico), it would have been nice to have access to an extra blanket for the bed. Second, in addition to the offer to prepare sandwiches for the guests, offering recommendations to guests for additional lunch options in the area for when they are out and about. Otherwise, we had a great stay and we look forward to staying at Casa Grande again!

Reviews.Title: “Please Rescue the Restaurant.”
Reviews.Author: Sleuthe
Reviews.Content: If my wife and I had even one AVERAGE meal out of two this place would get a 4 or 5. More on this later. An "I Survived Getting to the CGMR" badge should be awarded to all guests for completing the near death-defying, white knuckled drive up here. I found the drive to be fun for about the first 10 minutes. Hint...there was one confusing turn getting to the CGMR. Take the low road. Stayed one night in room #4. Front Desk service outstanding. Found room spartan, but clean, airy, and comfortable. Gorgeous, well maintained gardens. Incredible views of lush, jungle mountainsides. Good views of mountains from only a few rooms. Request rooms #4 or #5. This will cost you $5-10 more but worth it as this is by far the best feature of the CGMR. Small porch allows for a relaxing, meditative, experience for views. Hammock on porch more of a hindrance than convenience and should be detatchable from one end so it can be stowed up in porch rafters. Spring Fed onsite pool was refreshing to me. Too cold for wife. Now for the food and service at the restaurant. Horrible. Maybe they just had two bad days, we ordered the wrong things, or it was just the luck of the draw. First off you should understand that my wife and I felt trapped here for meals. I saw no other place for meals within proximity to CGMR. I'd advise you to eat at one of the route 10 roadside vendors on the way to here (about 30 min. out from CGMR...we did as I had a sneaky suspicion that the food was going to be below average) or bring your own food and grill/prepare for yourself (if this is allowable). We tried to enjoy Dinner /Breakfast at the CGMR restaurant. Dinner started with the fried combo. appetizer ( I think they are all fried) the only decent thing was the fried cheese. I had Mahi-Mahi, Wife had Salmon. Both specials. Nothing special about them. Both fish dishes were overcooked , dry, hard, and tasteless. This, after I specifically made a point of telling waitress not to overcook fish...twice) Each bite of my Mahi-Mahi could have been used as a sling shot projectile to kill chickens with. Waitress inattentive and indifferent. Never asked about meal. Breakfast. Ordered fresh fruit plate and the yougurt with raisins and walnuts. Tough to screw up yogurt. They didn't. Fresh Fruit? Wouldn't you expect, especially in PR, a sizeable and delicious plate of fruit? Not here. What arrived was a smallish single layered plate consisting of 1 thinly sliced banana, rindy, seedy, inedible grapefruit wedges and about 10 tiny pieces of an orange colored substance that was tasteless. One last note that the CGMR probably can't control but still annoying. This place bills itself as a QUIET, secluded retreat. It's really not as secluded as they would lead you to believe. I settled into the porch to relax after our disaster dinner to have a Manhattan and smoke a cigar. Within minutes a radio blared form a dwelling 20 feet below the resort. This lasted for an hour until 8:30PM. I wouldn't have minded if music was playing, but the radio seemed to be playing the calling/anouncing of a horse race. Because of the negatives the CGMR rates a 1 1/2 out of 5 to me. I'll give it a 2 because my wife is incredibly forgiving and there are no half ratings here. I could'nt stay here again unless I could make my own food or there is evidence that the restaurant has been rescued.

Reviews.Title: “What a heavenly place to visit”
Reviews.Author: miss_kitty76
Reviews.Content: I've read through many of these reviews and have to agree with most of them. This place is beautiful anytime of day, rain or shine. The staff is friendly, the rooms are clean and comfortable, and the food is awesome. I would definitely recommend purchasing the package that includes dinner and breakfast as food is difficult to find in that area. We also found it handy to have some basic snacks available in a cooler. The owner was very friendly and helpful and had a lot of activities available for people should they choose to take part. There was yoga early in the morning and a mid-morning guided hike to a waterfall. There was also a massage therapist on the grounds. One of my favorite aspects was the prohibition on radios and televisions. If you feel like taking a 10 minute walk up the road, there is a very small bar attached to a house on the right hand side. It's run by a Navy Veteran named Jose. Stop in for a good but inexpensive drink and a chat.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect Spot in the mountains”
Reviews.Author: ashimarob
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just returned from spending 3 nights at Casa Grande. It was fabulous - the staff is incredibly friendly and helpful and the location is a great alternative to the touristy areas near the beaches. If you open all the shutters in your room your really feel like you are in a treehouse - you feel the breeze and hear all the birds and the raindrops. It's very relaxing. The room itself is very simple, has a bit of a summer camp feel, not a bad thing to me personally, and is clean. The pool was nice and we greatly enjoyed our morning yoga classes. Not many of the guests took advantage of this service so we had basically our own personal class each day. The food was good, nothing too memorable, but nothing bad either. They have wi-fi in the main house but no tv or internet in the rooms themselves. The road up to the resort is taxing but it is well paved. We used Casa Grande as a base to explore the Cordillera Central region including the Rio Camuy Caverns and the Toro Negro Forest. If you are looking for a quiet, relaxing spot away from it all Casa Grande is the place.

Reviews.Title: “A Restorative, Peaceful Retreat”
Reviews.Author: Penelope7238
Reviews.Content: My husband and I found Casa Grande when a last minute change left us not going to Vieques. Heading into the mountains was not my husband's idea of fun - we live in the mountains, why would we want to see more mountains, he asked. However, by the time we got home he was calling Casa Grande his favorite place we stayed on the trip and the time spent in the mountains the most special. Casa Grande's accomodations are unadorned. If you want something plush, look elsewhere. However, our room was clean, the tiled bathroom nice, and the feeling of being somewhere truly different pervaded. Our room faced the mountains and we greatly enjoyed our private porch and hammock where we spent time reading and taking in the sounds of nature. Each night we fell asleep to the chorus of the coquis chirping away. If you're even vaguely interested in yoga - take Steve's morning class. It's special time spent reflecting and limbering up for either lazing about or heading out hiking. He is a gentle and kind instructor and makes the class accessible for all skill levels. The only slight downside I found was that I would have liked Casa Grande's menu to reflect a bit more Puerto Rican culture - though I understand that in choosing a limited number of items one much try to appeal to as many tastes as possible. Herbed chicken and spaghetti are pretty safe. On the upside the little indoor/outdoor cafe area is absolutely charming and a great place to while away some time drinking coffee and watching the wind blow. Personally I wouldn't recommend Casa Grande for small children unless they are the kind that are good at entertaining themselves. It's a quiet place and unruly children would rather disrupt the tranquility and most likely be unhappy themselves. If you go, MAKE SURE you head into Jiyuya to visit the Tanio craft co-op, Cemi museum and the coffee house/cafe at Hacienda San Pedro.

Reviews.Title: “Charming retreat for a day or two”
Reviews.Author: LudwigLeichardt
Reviews.Content: On arriving I was disappointed with Casa Grande as it didn't live up to the website photos and the location is not as remote as I imagined after visiting the website. However, the owners and staff are so friendly and charming and the surrounding area beautiful for walks and drives if you are a little independent and adventurous. We hiked in a couple of national parks and along the river but the national park is an hours drive. A previous reviewer had described the accommodations as a step above camping which I do not agree with at all. They certainly are not luxurious but clean and pleasant. I would recommend Casa Grande Mountain Retreat for a day or two.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful, peaceful place”
Reviews.Author: doctorpanda
Reviews.Content: We spent the first three nights of our honeymoon here. It was difficult to get to, as the website suggests, and we definitely found our GPS to be helpful. The staff was very gracious, but unobtrusive. We also found the guests to be like-minded travelers and very pleasant to be around. Our cabin was lovely and we had gorgeous views of the mountains and had a wonderful time napping and reading in the hammock on our porch. There are lots of treefrogs that croak at night and gecko type lizards everywhere, so if that's the kind of thing that may bother you, this place is not for you. There is not a lot to do, so we spent much of the time napping and reading. We went for drives during the day in search of lunch because the hotel does not serve lunch. There are places on the side of the road, but they do require a drive. The hotel was willing to make you sandwiches for lunch though. The meals were very good. Plenty of options for breakfast. The staff speaks English very well. The dinners were very good as well. The churrasco is excellent, the chicken stew was a little small and the fish of the day was very good. I would recommend the salad as a side.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful, Peaceful”
Reviews.Author: travelingpurr
Reviews.Content: Casa Grande is remote - making it perfect. It is a bit of a drive but its not terrible - just make sure you go during the day. The rooms are spare but really what more do you need than a clean bed and a private bath? They even provide a fan in each room. The hotel is set in the beautiful mountatins of central Puerto Rioc. You can lie in your hammock and never get tired of the view...especially when the clouds start and settle in the mountain valley. The food, on the other hand is sort of hit or miss. One night our dinner was absolutely fantastic; the next, not so much. Also, there is no lunch service and after making the drive you don't really feel much like driving again until its time to leave. But...do not hestitate to leave the property (turn left out of the gate) and walk about 20 minutes to the Villa de Pescados. It is one of those roadside bar/restaurants that you will see many examples of on your drive to the hotel. The owner/operator of the bar was really nice and we settled in for Medalla beers and some authentic criolla cuisine as it poured outside. The bar looked out over the mountain side as well with more beautiful views. Be a little forewarned though...there are no hours posted so I can't be sure of specific times they are open. We walked by and they were just opening at 1:30 on a Sunday afternoon....

Reviews.Title: “beautiful setting but some downsides”
Reviews.Author: volksdc
Reviews.Content: I stayed at casa grande in January 2007. The facility is located in a beautiful lush moutainous area, no doubt about that. As advertised the resort has simple, clean, rustic type rooms and the bed was comfortable , with fans (no a/c) but good ventilation. A hammock on your porch is a very nice touch. The pool was quite nice and relaxing in the mountain settting. The major downside to the resort is the cabins contain 3 or 4 seperate rooms in one structure and there is essentially zero noise insulation. The resort caters to families as well as couples and it is basically luck of the draw if you have a completely quiet experience or noisy neighbors,. They do have a quiet time cutoff of 11pm which was respected by most occupants and the soothing coqui frogs chirping was very pleasent. Also be aware the local road runs rigth in front of the resort so occasional traffic passes by. Yoga in the morning was relaxing albiet the occasional truck/automobile would come down the road and create noise. The food is reasonable but not gourmet. Getting to the resort requires navigating hairpin turns through the mountains, but for experienced drivers it is managable. Local activites include some pleasent hiking through lush vegitation with mountain and valley views, a lake with free boat ride which i did and found very pleasent. Horseback riding and kayaking is also available. The owners are friendly and helpful. In summary casagrande is located in a beautiful setting and has simple clean comfortable facilites with gorgeous views from your relaxing hammock. But be aware that noise from your neighbors, and their children may be a significant, albeit unpredictable downside.

Reviews.Title: “Relax and rejuvenate at Casa Grande”
Reviews.Author: gastup
Reviews.Content: At first when we looked at the pictures, Casa Grande looked a little too rustic, almost like Girl Scout camp on stilts. However, the simplicity of accommodations added to our enjoyment. Casa Grande is tucked away into the mountains outside of Utuado. The coquis chirp a lullaby all night and the roosters awaken you in the morning. Jungle Janes was convenient. Not having to drive after dinner made the marvelous Sangria made from Steve's recipe extra enjoyable. We tried other sangrias after our stay at the Casa Grande but none can compare. We stayed for one very short night and left feeling energized. Would I stay here again? Most definitely!! But next time, the stay will be longer.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely outside;Questionable within.”
Reviews.Author: gypsymoth_7
Reviews.Content: We stayed a single night here in order to be near Camuy Caves and the Arecibo Observatory. While the surroundings were beautiful, the rooms, especially for the price--$99--were pretty outrageous. I have since discovered that we paid more than we should have for the room, particularly as we were among only about four rooms occupied that night. Had we known what we were in for, we would have sought other accommodation. The food was quite good, BUT The bathroom was so dirty I could not find a clean spot to put our toothbrushes down. The management argued with us about the need to get it cleaned until I volunteered to clean it myself if they would give me the materials. At that point, they called someone in, who obviously understood the problem as she changed the sheets from the ones we could read the mattress tag through to new ones that were not only not threadbare but also lacked the dirt and spiders that we had had before. I also dislike looking up to see debris caught in cobwebs on the ceiling in a hundred-dollar room. Even after the cleaning, the shower was too dirty to be used without shower shoes. This is okay in a summer camp, not in a hundred-dollar room. We are too old for summer camp, and it's not what we were looking for. If it's not what you're looking for, this isn't a place for you, either.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing”
Reviews.Author: PantalaNagaPampa
Reviews.Content: As soon as we got there, we were blown away by the beauty of the place. The lush tropical grounds, banana and orange trees, all sorts of palm trees and flowering plants, it was paradise. The cabins scattered about the property are set high on stilts, with hammocks on the front decks, to take full advantage of the view overlooking the mountains. We felt as if we had landed somewhere in the middle of a South American jungle. We did the package deal, which consisted of the room, dinner and breakfast. For 3 of us it was about $60US a person. We stayed for one night, but two or three nights would have been better. This would have given us time to hike around some of the rivers and lakes in the area and to enjoy the peacefulness of being so far away from the mainstream tourist route. Getting to Utuado isnâ€™t bad. Route 22 and Route 10 are major roads. After Utuado, the road narrows and becomes quite curvy, but definitely drivable. If youâ€™ve been to Maui, think â€˜the road to Hanaâ€™, minus the waterfalls. The town of Utuado is a good size with gas stations, pharmacies and a grocery store. It took us about 2 hours to get there from San Juan Airport. After checking in, we did make a room change to be further away from the pool and the constant hum of its generator. The place was empty, so this wasnâ€™t a problem and the staff was more than accommodating. Our new room was furthest away from the main check-in area and allowed us to fall asleep to the sounds of the coqui frogs and intermittent showers of the rainforest. I recommend asking for one of these cabins. Iâ€™ve read the complaints in other reviews about the dÃ©cor of the rooms and I have to disagree. While they are basic, with tile floors, simple bedding, a dresser, a fan, lighting, and a private bath, everything was clean and in good shape. Thereâ€™s no phone or A/C, but the louvered windows allow a cool breeze to blow in, which makes it a comfortable temperature for sleeping (even for me, who has trouble sleeping when itâ€™s too hot). The restaurant is nice, but could use improvement. Dinner was served outside, at a candlelit table, on a covered verandah. The ambiance was great, but the food was a little disappointing. The salmon wasnâ€™t fresh and the stew was bland, but we just kept the wine flowing and enjoyed ourselves. Breakfast, on the other hand, was great. The fruit plate was made from the fruit trees on the grounds, the omelettes were tasty and the orange juice was freshly squeezed. To me, the good service and the beautiful setting made up for the â€˜just OKâ€™ dinner. Iâ€™ve certainly been to worse places. We really loved it here. During the rest of our vacation, we stayed in a typical, big name beach resort. With all its beauty, grandeur and amenities, it still couldnâ€™t keep us from thinking about the Casa Grande. If you like a little adventure, places off the beaten path and some tranquility, I think youâ€™ll love the place.

Reviews.Title: “great location with potential to improve”
Reviews.Author: wanderlust0037
Reviews.Content: I stayed for one night at the Casa Grande hoping to use it as a base for hikes etc. The drive there was spectacular and the setting gorgeous but the place itself was disappointing. The place looks a bit ramshackle from the outside. The rooms were very clean, large enough, clean, the fresh mountain temperature did not require air conditioning, but I heard every word from my early riser (5 am) neighbors despite speaking in low voices and every bathroom movement during the night. At 8 a.m. I had the impression that the whole resort was awake but in fact it was just the staff chatting on way to work. Mostly enjoyed the yoga class (additional) and the hammock on my balcony. Did not enjoy the dinner - lackluster and overpriced. Breakfast was fine - decent food for only $7.00. Travelling alone, I had hoped for more input and suggestions about enjoying the area but the management seemed friendly but not helpful with advice. Overall, I would say that it is great place to base some hiking or an interesting night away from the beaches, but do not expect any frills or a good night sleep if you have neighbors.

Reviews.Title: “Beautifully isolated, but spartan rooms”
Reviews.Author: zsazsa77
Reviews.Content: My husband & I stayed here for 1 night during our Puerto Rican honeymoon, on our way to Areceibo. It is VERY difficult to reach, as all the roads, though well-paved are windy nonstop as you go through the mountains. (Anyone who is sensitive to carsickness, be forewarned!) The setting of the resort, once you get there, is gorgeous. Surrounded by lush green mountains on all sides, the sound of nature is the only thing you'll hear at night (the coquis are very vocal!). The rooms are a bit summer camp-ish, with just the basics and are a bit small. But the hammock on the balcony is a nice touch. We had wanted to do the AM yoga class, but the week that we were there, the rain had washed out the road in front of the yoga instructor's house, so there was no yoga. I thought the food at Jungle Jane's was fine, especially as there is literally no place else to eat anywhere close by. The coffee there was very good. If you want to get away from it all (and are prepared for spartan accommodations), bring your bug spray and enjoy the views!

Reviews.Title: “Beautifull view, not so good room's”
Reviews.Author: tragaldavas
Reviews.Content: The view's are breath taking. But the rooms are spartan. There is a problem that people fail to mention. The wall's between the room's are very thin. So be prepared to listen everithing that happens in the room next door(Sex,snores, fight's, etc) . My wife and I had a good time but, we would like a more peacefull and private night. So we are not going back. 1. Staff: friendly and helpfull 2. Food: Great, no need to go elsewhere. 3. Facilities: beatifull, only problem are the room's (see above) 4.Events: The Joga class is a must.
